awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Elements: Data: HDR: Developing On-Demand Service Module for Mining Geophysical Properties of Sea Ice from High Spatial Resolution Imagery
awd_abstract_narration:
Sea ice acts as both an indicator and an amplifier of climate change. At present, there are multiple sources of  sea ice observations which are obtained from a variety of networks of sensors (in situ, airborne, and space-borne).  By developing a smart cyberinfrastructure element for the analysis of high spatial resolution (HSR) remote sensing images over sea ice, the science community is better able to extract important geophysical parameters for climate modeling. The project contributes new domain knowledge to the sea ice community.  This is accomplished by integrating HSR images that are spatiotemporally discrete to produce a more rapid and reliable identification of ice types, and by a standardized image processing that allows creating compatible sea ice products.  The cyberinfrastructure module is a value-added on-demand web service that can be naturally integrated with existing infrastructure.

The key objective is to develop a reliable and efficient on-demand Open Geospatial Consortium-compliant web service, which is capable of extracting accurate geographic knowledge of water, submerged ice, bare ice, melt ponds, deformed 'ridging' ice, ridge shadows, and other information from HSR images with limited human intervention. The embedded spatial-temporal analysis framework provides functions to search, explore, visualize, organize, and analyze the discrete HSR images and other related remote sensing data and field data. The project creates a data and knowledge web service for the Arctic sea ice community by integrating computer vision and machine learning algorithms, computing resources, and HSR image data and other useful datasets. The conceptual model improves data flow, so users would query data, download value-added data, and have more consistent results across various sources of information.  This creates new opportunities for scientific analysis that minimizes the investment of time in processing complex and spatiotemporally-discrete HSR imagery. The project includes a strong emphasis on teaching and development of the next-generation workforce through course curricula development, involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in research, and the offering of summer workshops for K-12 teachers (funded by other agencies). The collected images and results of the image analyses will be shared with the public in a timely manner through the NSF Arctic Data Center.

This award by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by EarthCube and the Office of the Polar Programs Arctic Natural Sciences Program, within the NSF Directorate for Geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Arctic sea ice is a sensitive climate change indicator. High spatial resolution (HSR) imagery is critical in Arctic Sea ice research for verifying the Earth observation satellite data, extracting sea ice physical parameters, and calibrating/validating climate models. However, these images are discrete in space and time, in big volume, and are often not included in the existing Arctic data centers. The Arctic Image spatial-temporal Cyberinfrastructure (ArcCI) addresses the above-mentioned issue by collecting and integrating HSR images for analyzing scientific phenomena to support polar science. The ArcCI system leveraged cloud computing and on-demand capabilities to manage and organize the highly discrete HSR images and provided interoperable interfaces for exchanging information at data and product levels. Additionally, the ArcCI system provided a spatial-temporal visual analytical service for sea ice movement through an interactive and intuitive Arctic web map interface.

The ArcCI system serve as a fully functional model on providing on-demand services using the cloud computing technologies with highlighting features such as (1) single/multiple HSR images upload and metadata retrieval, (2) search and sort by image metadata, (3) an open-source Machine Learning (ML)-based image classification method to classify the HSR images (4) an automatic batch image classification and physical parameter extraction, (5) semi-automatic ML-based training data labeling tool, (6) share with peers and reused by other CI and polar projects as open source, and (6) spatial-temporal visual analytics of sea ice evolution. The algorithms, workflows, and visualization technologies developed in the ArcCI system facilitated polar science research and analysis for data discovery which can be expanded to other Earth Science applications such as forestry, Land Use Land Cover (LULC) change, urban planning, oceanography etc.

Through community outreach and workshops, the Earth Science, polar and cryosphere scientists had hands-on experience with the ArcCI system. During these workshops, the participants explored the HSR images and relevant metadata information such as image acquisition date, size, latitude, longitude, altitude etc. And conducted visual analytics interactively. Multiple users uploaded and processed the HSR images at the same time leveraging the scalable, on-demand cloud computing capabilities. Specifically, the users uploaded their own HSR images that were then processed and classified in a high-performance manner seamlessly. Most of the researchers gave positive feedback during these sessions with comments on improving the user experience. In short, the ArcCI module assisted the polar scientists in investigating polar sea ice and can be easily transferred to other HSR image processing research projects.

The project team published 30+ peer-reviewed papers on developing interactive CI system, sea Ice detection and classification algorithms and related applications. Four graduate students received their degrees and are working for CI or sea ice/STEM research companies; 20+ REU students have engaged in the project; and 100+ participants have attended four workshops conducted for and/or at IGS (International Glaciological Society), EarthCube, and Cryosphere communities. Through these community workshops, many scientists expressed their willing to see a fully operational ArcCI system to support their research, and provided many constructive feedbacks to improve this platform.
